title: Between 1 October 2018 and 30 September 2019, will an armed group from the Philippines engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in the Philippines?
preds: It seems that the campaign will continue, but the number of extra-judicial killings may have peaked and won't reach the threshold stated in the question.

https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/11/rodrigo-duterte-criticised-duterte-death-squad-threat-181128055121199.html
Another killing spree has been declared by the Prez.   Should be able to get those numbers up pretty quickly; everybody wants to please the boss.

The extrajudicial killing of drug addicts and traffickers by police and security forces could very well continue and result in 1000 deaths during the time period. But given the emphasis on mass killings and specific civilian groups, it's hard to tell if this would count. For most of these questions, a specific civilian groups means an ethnic group or religious minority. If not for these qualifiers, I would go higher on this question.

It doesn't seem like the extrajudicial killings in the drug war have stopped, though there's some signs that it's transitioning toward more "vigilante justice" rather than killings by uniformed police. Pushback form the ICC might have an effect, but as of a few days ago, Duterte was still insisting that his drug war would continue unabated through the end of his term in 2022. It's possible that the rate of killings, or at least ones that are confirmably perpetrated by police, will decrease, but more likely than not people will continue to be killed in large numbers.
